STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 24, 2021
Lynn Sepolen
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
RE: License #: CB330201019
St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
Dear Ms. Sepolen:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
3/3/21. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP failed to achieve compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge-Garnaat, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
235 Grand, Ste 1305
P.O. Box 30650
Lansing, MI 48909
(517) 899-6024
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: St Vincent Catholic Charities
Licensee Address: 2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 394-9450

Name of Facility: St Vincent Catholic Charities-Child Welfare
Facility Address: 2800 West Willow
Lansing, MI 48917
Facility Telephone #: (517) 323-4734

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12213 Record Management.
An agency shall do all of the following with respect to
maintenance of required records:
(a) Protect each record against destruction and damage.
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
(c) Store and maintain each record in a manner to ensure
confidentiality and to prevent unauthorized access.
Throughout the inspection multiple documents were not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
The documents were requested and several of them were unable to be found.
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the plan
to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621, and
known as the child protection law.
During a Special Evaluation on Foster Parent A the agency received information that
the Foster Mother hit the foster child with a stick. The Special Evaluation Report,
case record, and a review of MiSACWIS intakes for Foster Parent A found that the
agency did not call in the allegations to Central Intake.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
2 of 3 foster Homes files reviewed did not have a recommendation submitted to the
department 15 days before the license expired.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
4

(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
During a Special Evaluation Foster Parent A was found in violation of R 400.9404
Behavior management because she was found to have spanked her foster child and
hit the child with a stick. The CAP for this violation indicated the Foster Parent was
to review agency policy. This is not a sufficient CAP for the violation cited as it did
not ensure the safety of the child in the home.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
During the Special Evaluation for Foster Parent B the agency did not indicate they
talked to the alleged victim.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
3 or 6 Foster Care files reviewed did not have an updated dental exam.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
5

(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care.
1 of 6 Foster Care files reviewed did not have placement outlines documenting the
required information was given to the caregiver for all placement changes.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
3 of 19 Updated Service Plans were completed late.
 1 plan was 1 day late
 1 plan was 2 days late
 1 plan was 27 days late
1/ of 19 Updated Service Plans was not completed. The USP was due on 2/3/21,
and as of 3/3/21 the report had not been started.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(a) Dates, types, and places of agency contacts and persons
contacted.
6

1 of 19 Updated Service Plan’s reviewed did not include all contacts.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.54 Psychotropic Medication, Informed Consent
Ensure that informed consent is obtained and documented in
writing in connection with each psychotropic medication
prescribed to a child in DHHS custody.
1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have documentation that an informed
consent was completed for prescribed psychotropic medication.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-03B Initial Safety Screen
Caseworkers must complete a DHS-588, Initial Relative Safety
Screen, for all adult relatives who express an interest in
placement, within five business days of the relative's written
request for placement consideration.
1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have a Relative Safety Screen in the file.
FOM 722-03 Placement Change
DHHS-69 is required for placement changes.
1 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have all the DHHS-69’s completed for every
placement change.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
All medical information required by policy and/or law must be
pro-vided to the foster parent. This includes copies of the
7

medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• The child’s foster care provider:
Receipt of the medical passport by the required parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
4 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have all required medical passports
uploaded with signatures.
This is a repeat violation cited during then 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP
on 4/13/20.
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
7 of 20 Services Plan’s reviewed were approved late.
 1 ISP was approved 49 days late
 1 USP was approved 11 days late
 1 USP was approved 12 days late
 1 USP was approved 20 days late
 1 USP was approved 27 days late
 1 USP was approved 29 days late
 1 USP was approved 31 days late
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
Caregiver
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates
that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
8

12 of 20 Service plans reviewed did not have a caregiver signature on the PATP.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
over 14-Years Old
The parents and a child over 14 are required to sign each
Parent Agency Treatment Plan
9 of 20 Service Plans did not include the parents and/or youth’s signature on the
PATP.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
5 of 6 Foster Care files reviewed had late entry of face-to-face contacts.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2019 Renewal Inspection with a CAP
accepted on 5/1/19 and during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP on
4/13/20.
722-06B Family Team Meetings
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual transition
planning for youth every six months from age 16 until case
closure
• 90 day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
Requested by family
9

3 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have all of the required FTM’s.
Policy 722-6B FTM documentation
The DHHS 1105 must be completed after every FTM and
placed in MiSACWIS within 7 days.
4 of 6 foster care files reviewed did not have the documentation for all of the
completed FTM’s.
This is a repeat violation cited during the 2020 Interim Inspection with a CAP
on 4/13/20.
SRM 200 FINGERPRINTS: Personnel Training
All personnel, contractors, vendors, and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete Security
Awareness Training (SAT). SAT is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access and
every two years thereafter.
9 of 12 employees who has/had access to CW-CHRI did not complete SAT within
the required time frame.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Ensure all sections of MiSACWIS that go into the service plans and PATP’s
are updated with current information.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were not any incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
A Special Evaluation was completed on Foster Parent A when she reported she
spanked her foster child. During the investigation the Foster Mother also admitted to
10

hitting the child with a stick. The agency found the parent in violation of R 400.9404
Behavior Management. The agency implemented a corrective action plan which
entailed the Foster Parent reviewing agency policy. This is not a sufficient CAP for
this type of violation. This was addressed with the agency management team and
have been found in violation of R 400.12325 License recommendation. The home is
now closed so no further follow-up is needed.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Special Investigation 2021C0112007 was initiated when it was reported an Agency
Worker was aware an adult was residing in the same foster home as a foster youth
and failed to do a background check on the adult. It is alleged that the man is being
investigated for sexually abusing the child. The agency was found in violation of R
400.12309 Records Check because the worker did not complete a background
check on an individual suspected of living in the home. An additional finding found
the agency in violation of R 400.12206 Staff Qualifications because the foster care
worker did not visit the youth in his/her home after being told to by her supervisor.
An appropriate corrective action plan was submitted and approved on 1/21/21.
The agency has struggled greatly with staff turnover, an unqualified program director,
and COVID. This is evidenced by the large number of violations including repeat
violations. The agency currently has a qualified leader in place who has been in
charge of the adoption department at the agency for years. The adoption department
did not have any violations during this review which speaks to the new director’s
ability to accomplish the task needed to achieve compliance.
VII. Summary of Analyst Findings
The field analyst, Cynthia Szott, completed visits to three foster homes and three
unlicensed relative homes. In one of the three unlicensed homes there were not
working smoke detectors and there was a leak in the ceiling causing damage to the
ceiling tiles. The agency bought the relative new smoke detectors and provided
pictures that they were hung. The worker confirmed they were in working order during
a visit to the home.
Regarding the ceiling, the foster care supervisor confirmed that a contractor found no
current leaks. The stains and missing ceiling tile were most likely due to an overflow
in the bathroom above. The agency is working with the relative to get a grant to fix
the ceiling. Currently there are no more safety issues in the home.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes, rules, MISEP, and contract/policy requirements. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
11

3/19/21
